To report a bug or make a suggestion regarding the &app; application or this manual, see the Buzztard website at http://www.buzztard.org.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; is a music composer for the GNOME desktop. It partly follows the concepts of programs like SoundTracker, FastTracker and the like, but is based on a modern media engine (gstreamer). This engine supports virtual sound generator and effects in the form of numerous plugins.

During the next section we describe the concept of the &app; and also compare it to similar applications. If you are familiar with some of those, the retrospective sections should help to understand the way &app; works.
The main chapter of the help system is separated into these sections:

sect2.title: The concept behind &app;
sect2.para: &app; follows the concept of tracker applications. this is quite different when compared to other music composers. The tracker concept is more focused on the data.
Important design criteria are: fast, keyboard accessible, system ui.

sect2.title: Comparison to Buzz
sect2.para: &app; is inspired of lot by Buzz. Some features are still missing and some things already work better. The UI in is not a 1-to-1 copy, for Buzz users the UI will still look familiar.

&app;:
can render songs to wav/mp3,ogg-vorbis/... including song-meta-data (tags) and multi track exports
uses color-codes for machine-types through its ui
generates cleaner machine UIs (collapsing parts, more distinct widgets)
has a scalable machine view
can use beats other that 4/4
shows volume and pan on wire
does balance on stereo wires
has analyzers and mixing controls in sequence view
can have multiple wire-analyzers open
can be remote controlled with UPnP a/v software
supports HID input devices for effect control (e.g. joysticks)
can't yet use samples
can't yet reconnect machines reliably while playing

sect1.title: The main window
sect1.para: After starting the &app; Music Editor, you will see the main window. If you start the application without specifying an initial file (as a parameter on the command line or by double clicking a song in Nautilus), the window will look like this.

textobject.phrase: Shows &app; main window with menu bar, toolbars, editor views and status area.

sect1.para: On the very top of the window is the menu bar. Below one finds the toolbar. And below again are tabs to switch between various views. Each view is for editing certain aspects of the song. On the bottom is a status bar.
Many parts in the UI show tooltips with explanations. Hover the mouse pointer over the region and wait a moment.

sect2.title: The menu bar
sect2.para: The menu bar gives you access to file operations, standard editing function, settings and help.

The File menu allows to start a new song, load and save songs, as well as end the program. Songs need other resources in order to be played. These are the sound-generators and effects that are used and eventually digital audio-samples. When loading a song &app; checks if all needed resources are available and if not lists them in one dialog (FIXME: document and link).

sect2.title: The tool bar
sect2.para: In contrast to the menu bar the tool bar only shows common operations as shortcuts. On the right end the toolbar shows a volume-meter for each audio-channel and a volume control.

sect2.title: The song views
sect2.para: Each part of a song is represented by a specialized views which one can switch to with the tabs. Next we briefly introduce each tab, where in the next sub section they will be described in detail.

sect3.title: The machine view of a song
sect3.para: A song utilizes sound generators, effects and sinks - all called machines. A new machine can be added from the context menu that appear on a right click over the page area. Machines can be moved around by grabbing them with the mouse and dragging them around. To connect machines, move pointer over the source, press shift+left mouse-button and drag the wire to the target machine. The wire turns green, if the connect can be made.

The machines have a state switch in the upper left corner. You can click this to set it to working state. Additionally holding Ctrl, Win (Mod) or Ctrl+Win keys sets the machine to mute, solo or bypass. Not all machines support all these states.

Wires have volume and panorama control support. A left-click on the pointer-shape in the middle of the wire open a volume popup. A click outside closes it again. Shift+left-click opens the panorama control.
Machines and wires have context menus. The menu for the wire can be accessed by right clicking over the pointer shape in the middle.

note.title: Limitations
note.para: Adding/removing machines and adding new wires while a song is playing, will most likely break playback.

sect3.title: The pattern view of a song
sect3.para: Patterns are the building blocks of a song. They are short snippets of events for one machine, that can be reused in the sequence.

In the page toolbar one can select the machine and the pattern for the machine. Pattern names in gray color indicated that the pattern is not used in the sequence (thus save to be removed or changed).
A context menu in the pattern area allows to create new patterns and modify existing ones.
To switch to the sequence editor press Enter while the pattern editor has focus.

sect3.title: The sequence view of a song
sect3.para: A song consists of several tracks (columns), where in each track patterns are played. The rows are time slots.
The sequence header for each track shows the name of the machine, mute, solo. bypass buttons (depending whether it is a generator, effect or sink) and a level-meter.

One can navigate around using cursor keys. When changing tracks, the list of patterns on the right is updated to show the patterns for the current machine. Again gray pattern label color indicates that the pattern is not in use. Patterns can be entered into tracks by pressing the associated key (shown left to the pattern name in the list). To switch to the pattern editor with the pattern the cursor is over selected, press Enter.
To set play position click with left-mouse button in the first column at the desired time location. To modify the loop start/end instead hold down the Ctrl or Win (Mod) key while clicking.

To expand the sequence, scroll down with the cursor and press Ctrle to set the end-line. If the cursor is above the end-line, pressing CtrlE will set the loop-end marker. To set the loop-begin marker press Ctrlb.

It is also possible to insert and delete full rows or just entries in a track. The shortcuts for this are Ctrli to insert a full row and Ctrld to remove a full row. To only insert or remove inside the current track hold the Shift key in addition.

sect3.title: The wavetable view of a song
sect3.para: The wavetable hold sampled audio snippet that can be used e.g. from tracker sources.
Samples can be loaded, played and previewed when browsing.

note.title: Limitations
note.para: No waveform display, no details shown and no use of loaded waves yet.

sect3.title: The information view of a song
sect3.para: This page allows you to change song parameters, such as speed and timing resolutions and to enter information about the song. The meta data will be used for the tags when creating a final mix-down.

sect2.title: The status bar
sect2.para: The status bar that is located at the bottom of the window. On the left side it shows the status of longer operations like saving and loading with a text message. On the right side, it displays the length of the song, the loop range, the playback position and the current CPU usage.
